reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: I’ve built my career investing in consumer goods, insurance, railroads and simple industrials—not cutting-edge automotive technology. Electric vehicles, battery chemistry and full self-driving software sit well outside my circle of competence, so I wouldn’t trust my judgment here. 2. Competitive Moat: Tesla has a strong brand and early mover status, but auto manufacturing is capital-intensive with low switching costs and fierce competition. I’d need to see a truly enduring advantage before betting decades of capital. 3. Management Quality: Elon Musk is undeniably driven, but I prefer managers who think like owners, allocate capital conservatively and demonstrate consistency. Tesla’s history of unpredictable moves and heavy R&D spending raises red flags for my style. 4. Financial Health: With insufficient data provided, I can’t verify consistent earnings, cash flows or a fortress balance sheet—the bedrock of any Buffett holding. 5. Valuation: No reliable intrinsic value estimate or margin of safety is available here, and paying up for hype rarely suits my approach. 6. Long-Term Prospects: While EV adoption may grow, the space is crowded with legacy automakers and new entrants investing heavily. I see too many uncertainties around regulation, raw materials and autonomous rollout. 7. Portfolio Comparison: I’d much rather own a business I understand—like Coca-Cola, Apple or BNSF—at a fair price than a company I can’t value with confidence. On balance, this is a no for me.
